questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for PID except?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy is not a risk factor for PID.

Risk factors of PID:

  • Menstrual teenagers
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Absence of contraceptive pills
  • Previous history of PID
  • IUCD users

Protective factors of PID:

  • Barrier methods (condoms, diaphragm)
  • Oral contraceptive pills
  • Pregnancy
  • Menopause

choices.text: Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to primary focus

questions.text: Which of the following is false about genital tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The disease is commonly bilateral and subsequently spread to other genital organs and peritoneum.

Pathogenesis of Genital tuberculosis

  • Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis (95%) and Mycobacterium bovis (5%)
  • Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to primary focus.
  • primary focus being lungs>lymph node>abdomen or generalised miliary infection.
  • Mode of spread is hematogenous or via lymphatics rarely by direct contact with affected intra-abdominal or peritoneum.
  • Fallopian tubes are affected first, disease is commonly bilateral in distribution, subsequently spreading to other genital organs and peritoneum.
  • Bilateral pelvic nodes involvement often follows.

Vulvo-vaginal involvement is usually secondary to uterine involvement

choices.text: Microscopically, granulomas and chronic inflammatory infiltrates with hyperplasia can be mistaken as carcinoma
Tubes are enlarged, roughened, may show presence of greyish tubercles
Ampullary part of the tube appears dilated with fimbrial end open and pouting

questions.text: All of the following are related to Tubercular salpingitis except?
questions.solution:
Fimbriae are often spared, even in advanced form of disease presenting with bilateral tubal masses, giving the tubes the typical tobacco pouch appearance

Fallopian tube lesion in Tuberculosis:

  • Involvement is 100% and bilateral, secondary to haematogenous spread
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance: Tubes appear dilated with fimbrial end open and pouting
  • External surface: Greyish with tubercles

On cut section: lumen has yellowish grey caseous matter or serosanguinous fluid (Tuberculous haematosalpinx) and pyosalpinx.

questions.text: The most common genital organ involved in tuberculosis is?
questions.solution: Frequency of tuberculosis in genital organs:

questions.text: The fastest method to detect Mycobacterium is?
questions.solution:
• NAAT detects tuberculosis within few hours.
  • PCR is rapid, sensitive and specific method of detecting mycobacterial DNA, and reports available in 24 hours.
  • BACTEC: It is a rapid culture method where radioactive carbon-labelled substrate such as palmitic acid or formic acid is used as marker for bacterial growth, it takes 5-7 days to culture.

Semen culture: Advised in vulvo vaginal tuberculosis, take longer duration with unsatisfactory results compared to another test

questions.text: Gold standard test for the diagnosis of PID is?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopy is the confirmatory test for diagnosis of PID but not routinely done.

  • Laparoscopy is reserved for cases where differential diagnosis is Salpingitis, appendicitis or ectopic pregnancy or in case of nonresponding pelvic mass.

USG and Culdocentesis are also done but gold standard are laparoscopy

questions.text: Which of the following orgasm causes maximum damage to the fallopian tube?
questions.solution: Chlamydial infection causes more damage to the mucosa and the wall of the tube than gonorrhoea, leading to fibrosis and tubal blockage

choices.text: Single IM injection of Ceftriaxone with oral doxycycline and oral metronidazole for 14 days
Oral Ofloxacin and oral Metronidazole for 14 days
Single dose of Ceftriaxone injection with oral Azithromycin for 14 days

questions.text: A 30-year-old female complains of lower abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge. Her pulse rate is 98/min, temperature is 101 F, WBC and ESR are raised. Per vaginal examination reveals lower abdominal tenderness and cervical motion tenderness. What is the best treatment option for her?
questions.solution:
The best treatment is Single IM injection of Ceftriaxone with oral Doxycycline and oral metronidazole for 14 days.

The diagnosis is Pelvic inflammatory disease.

Sexually transmitted organisms, especially N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis, are implicated in many cases.

The best treatment for OPD management of PID is:

  • Inj.Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose + Doxycycline 100 mg BD x 14 days + Metronidazole 500mg BD x 14 days.

Best parenteral treatment for PID is:

  • Inj Cefotetan 2g IV BD + Doxycycline 100mg BD or
  • InJ Cefoxitin 2g IV QID + Doxycycline 100mg BD

To minimize disease transmission, women should be instructed to abstain from sexual intercourse until therapy is completed, symptoms have resolved, and sex partners have been adequately treated

questions.text: Long standing pelvic inflammation may lead to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Long standing pelvic inflammatory disease may lead to:

Pyometra: Pyometra is collection of pus in the uterine cavity

choices.text: Mycobacterium can be grown from menstrual blood

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement with respect to Silent PID
questions.solution:
Dysmenorrhea rarely ever occurs in PID.

Pain is uncommon and is a result of subacute PID

questions.text: Which two sexually transmitted infections can pass from mother to child during delivery causing eye infections in the neonate?
questions.solution:
• Ophthalmia neonatorum can be transmitted from mother to child during delivery in genital chlamydiasis and gonorrhoea.
  • Systemic treatment is recommended for ophthalmia neonatorum due to Chlamydia trachomatis with erythromycin.

choices.text: Men are most likely asymptomatic but efficient transmitters of this organism
In severe cases the regional mucosa may be red with petechial lesions and the cervix has been described as a 'strawberry cervix'
Simultaneous treatment of the patient and her sexual contacts will decrease the chance of recurrences
The cyst form of the life cycle is the most common method of transmission

questions.text: You see a 20-year-old female for complaints of vaginal itching, discharge, pain with intercourse and discomfort with urination. She has had 3 different sexual partners over the past 2 years. As part of your workup, you do a wet mount of vaginal secretions and see a flagellated organism about the size of a white blood cell with 'twitching motility' that makes you think of Trichomonas vaginalis. Which statement is false regarding Trichomonas?
questions.solution:
There is only one stage in the life cycle of Trichomonas, trophozoite.

Hence, the transmission occurs sexually via the trophozoite.

T. vaginalis inhabits the lower genital tract of females and the urethra and prostate of males.

Men infected with T. vaginalis are usually asymptomatic but can transmit the infection sexually.

In contrast, infection in women, which has an incubation period of 5 to 28 days, is usually symptomatic and manifests with malodorous vaginal discharge (often yellow), vulvar erythema and itching, dysuria or urinary frequency.

All sexual partners must be treated concurrently (Metronidazole) to prevent reinfection, especially from asymptomatic males

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most common problem associated with the use of condom:
questions.solution: Directions for use of condom the condom should be put on by unrolling it over the erect penis after pulling back the foreskin, before there is any contact between the male and female organs. An air free space should be left by squeezing the tip and holding it up, till it is unrolled fully for better collection of semen. It should be used only once. It should not be inflated for testing. Vaseline oils, skin lotions, cold creams, should not be used as they increase the chance of rupture. If lubrication is needed, glycerine, K-Y jelly or spermicidal jelly can be used. Soon after discharge, the male should withdraw the penis holding the condom firmly against his body to increase the effectiveness, a dose of spermicidal jelly or foam tablet may be used at the same time. In case of breakage, slippage, or defective use, women should report or use emergency contraceptive within 72 hours and a spermicidal agent should be quickly inserted into the vagina. Advantages of condom Condoms gives very good protection against STDs. These includes syphilis gonorrhoea, trichomoniasis, moniliasis, nongonococcal urethritis, and infection with Chlamydia and Herpes virus. They are the only contraceptives to protect against HIV and against sexually transmitted hepatitis B Virus. Condoms reduce the chances of developing cervical dysplasia and cancer cervix (by preventing HPV infection) Disadvantages It can lead to contact dermatitis in female partners. Failure rate 12%

questions.text: The most common cause of UTI?
questions.solution:
UropathogenicE. coliform the gut is the cause of 80 to85% of community-acquired urinary tract infections

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is the cause in 5 to10% of community-acquired urinary tract infections

Healthcare-associated urinary tract infections (mostly related to urinary catheterization) involve a much broader range of pathogens-E. coli (27%), Klebsiella (11%), Pseudomonas (11%), Candida albicans (9%), and Enterococcus (7%) among others

E coli are usually transmitted to the urethra from the bowel, with females at greater risk due to their anatomy. After gaining entry to the bladder. Coli is able to attach to the bladder wall and form a bio film that resists the body's immune response.

Fallopian tube lesion in Tuberculosis:

Tubercular salpingitis resembling tobacco pouch.



Under surface of liver showing violin string

questions.text: Which of the following is expected to be LEAST effectively treated with a member of the penicillin family?
questions.solution: While almost any antibiotic can cause pseudomembranous colitis, some antibiotics are more commonly linked to pseudomembranous colitis than others, including: Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin (Cipro) and levofloxacin. Penicillins, such as amoxicillin and ampicillin. Clindamycin (Cleocin)

questions.text: Metronidazole is commonly used to treat trichomonas infections and bacterial vaginosis. When prescribed, patients are warned against concurrent use or ingestion of which o the following due to an increased incidence of associated side effects?
questions.solution: It is best to avoid alcohol while taking metronidazole. Alcohol can cause reactions in addition to the regular side effects of this drug>

choices.text: Standing upright quickly rom sitting or supine positions

questions.text: You prescribe oral doxycycline to the patient described in Question 3-23. She should be cautioned against which o the following while taking this medication due to the increased potential or an adverse reaction?
questions.solution: Doxycycline may cause your skin to be more sensitive to sunlight than it is normally. Exposure to sunlight, even for short periods of time, may cause skin rash, itching, redness or other discoloration of the skin, or a severe sunburn.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with recent onset of mild dysuria, a foul vaginal discharge, and vaginal spotting. A saline preparation of her vaginal secretions is shown below. Your patient has had this infection be ore and relates a convincing history of a significant allergic reaction to metronidazole. What is the best option or treatment?
questions.solution: Bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis, and vulvovaginal candidiasis are the most common infectious causes of vaginitis. Bacterial vaginosis occurs when the normal lactobacilli of the vagina are replaced by mostly anaerobic bacteria. Diagnosis is commonly made using the Amsel criteria, which include vaginal pH greater than 4.5, positive whiff test, milky discharge, and the presence of clue cells on microscopic examination of vaginal fluid. Oral and topical clindamycin and metronidazole are equally effective at eradicating bacterial vaginosis. Symptoms and signs of trichomoniasis are not specific; diagnosis by microscopy is more reliable. Features of trichomoniasis are trichomonads seen microscopically in saline, more leukocytes than epithelial cells, positive whiff test, and vaginal pH greater than 5.4. Any nitroimidazole drug (e.g., metronidazole) given orally as a single dose or over a longer period resolves 90 percent of trichomoniasis cases

questions.text: Recommended treatment of uncomplicated gonorrhoea o the cervix takes into account recent development of drug resistance to quinolones and the declining efficacy of a previously avored cephalosporin. The most current treatment guideline rom the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (2015) lists which o the following as the pre-erred regimen?
questions.solution: The CDC currently recommends that patients with uncomplicated gonococcal infections of the pharynx be treated with a regimen consisting of a single dose of ceftriaxone 250 mg IM in addition to a single oral dose of azithromycin 1 g
